div.p:
That there is one onely true Faith, and what
the vertue thereof is.
Being cut off with the
shortnesse of time, & de
teined by the excellencie
of the matter, I coulde
Inot in my last Sermon
make an end of al that I had determi
ned to speake touching faith now ther
fore, by the grace of the holy spirite, I
will adde the rest of the argument
which seemeth yet to be behinde. Pray
to the Lorde, that that which by mans
voice is brought to our eares, may by ye
finger of God be writte in our hearts,
True faith is ignoraunt of all divi
sion, for there is, saith the Apostle, one
Lorde, one Faith, one Baptisme, God
& Father of all. For, there remayneth
from the beginning of the world even
unto the end thereof, one and the same
faith in al the elect of God. God is one
& the same for ever, the only Wel of al
goodnesse, that can never bee drawne
dry. The trueth of God, fro the begin
ning of the world, is one & the same, set
forth to me in the word of God. Ther
fore the obiect and foundation of faith,
that is God & the word of God, remain
for ever one and the selfe same.
In one and the self same faith with
us have all the elect ever since the first
creation of the world beleeved, that un
to us through Christ al good things are
freely given, and that all trueth neces
sarie to bee beleeved is declared in the
word of the Lord: wherefore, the faith,
ful of ye old worlde, have alwaies setled
their faith on God and his worde : so
that now without all doubt, there can
not be any more than one true faith,
I know very well, that in the world
there are sowed manie and sundrye
faithes, that is to say, religions. For
there is the Indian faith, the Jewish
faith, the faith of the Mahometistes, &
the faith of the Gregorias, and yet not
withstading there is but one true chri
stian faith, the abridgement whereof
is contained in the articles of our be
leefe, and is taught at the ful in the sa
cred Scriptures of both the Testa
ments. I know also that there are sun
dry beleefes of men, resting upon sun
dry thinges, and beleeving that which
is contrarie to true faith: but yet ne
verthelesse there remaineth but one
true beleefe in God & his word, (which
is) an undoubted persuasion and confi
dence of things most true, and allured
ly certeine.
This confidence doth growe with
increase in the mindes of hte faithtul, &
contrarily decreaseth againe and ut
terly faileth. And for that cause the A
postles besought the Lord saying: Lord
increase our saith. And Paul the Apo
stle doth in his writinges every where
wish to the faithful the increase of the
spirit & faith. David also, before him
prayed, saying: G God create a cleane
heart within mee, and take not thy
holy spirite from mee. For hee had
seene how that from saul, whome hee
succeeded in the kingdome, the good spi
rite of God was departed, and that in
steade therof the wicked spirit had en
tred into his minde which tormented
him verie pitifully. Hereunto belon
geth that faying in the gospel, To eve
rie one that hath shalbe given, and
from him that hath not shalbe taken
away that which he hath not, or that
he maketh no account of, and shalbee
given to him that hath. Neither was
it in vain, that the Lord said to Peter,
I have prayed for thee Peter, that
thy faith taile not. For Paul spea
keth of some in his time that made
shipwracke of their owne faith, and
overthrew the faith of other. And to
what ende I pray you, doe wee daily
heare the word of God, and make our
humble petitions to the Lorde, but be
cause we looke for increase of godlines,
& his aide to keepe us that we fall not
from true faith: Verily Paul to the
Thessalonians, saith:r wee pray ear
nestly day and night to see yousper
sonally, and to supply that which is
wanting in your taith. And a little
before, he said: For this cause I sent F
motheus, that I might be certified of
your faith, least by any meanes the
tempter had tempted you, and so our
Jabour had beene of no effect. The
same Apostle also in his Epistle to the
Ephesians saith: Christ gave some
Apostles, some Prophets, some Pa
stours ft teachers to the restoring of
the saintes unto the building of the
body of Christ, untill we all meete to
gether in the unitie of faith, and the
acknowledging of the sonne of God,
unto a perfect man, unto the measure
of age of the fulnesse of Christ, so that
now we be no longer children: Ther
fore so long as we live, we learne that
our faith may not be perfect, & if so be
at any time it shall bee weakened by
temptations, that then it may bee re
paired, and againe confirmed. And
in this diversitie(I meane) in this in
crease and weakenesse of faith, there
is no partition or division, for the felfe
roote and substance of faith doeth al
wayes remaine, although it bee at
some time more, & at sometime lesse,
In like manner, faith is not therefore
changed or cut in sunder, because one
is called generall faith, and another
particular faith. For generall faith is
no other than that, which believeth
that al the words of God are true, and
that God hath a good will to mankind.
Particular faith believeth nothing
contrarie to this, onely that which is
common to all, the faithfull applyeth
particularly to himself, helieving that
God is not well minded towarde o
thers alone, but even unto him also.
So then, it bringeth the whole into
partes, and that which is generall in
to particularities. For whereas by
generall faith he believeth that all the
wordes of God are true: in the same
fort by particular faith he doth believe
that the foule is immortall, that our
bodies rise againe, that the faithfull
shalbe saved, the unbelivers destroied,
and whatsoever else is of this forte,
taught to bee believed in the worde of
God. Moreover, the disputation tou
ching faith powvred into us, and faitl
that we our selves get, touching for
mall faith, and faith without fashion,
I believe to bee beaten out of them
which of them selves doe bring these
new disputations into the Church.
True faith is obteined by no stregth
or merite of man, but is poured ints
him of God, as I declared in my last
Sermon: and though man obtaine it
by harkning unto the word of God, yet
neverthelesse, it is wholy imputed to
ye grace of god. For unlesse this grace
do worke in wardly in the heart of the
hearer, ye preacher that laboureth outs
wardly doth bring no profit at all. We
reade in the third chapter of S. Augu
stines booke, De preedestinatione Sanfto
rum. That once he was in an error be
cause hee thought that that faith,
wherewith wee believe in God, is not
the gift of God, but that it was in us as
of out selves, et that by it wee doe ob
tein the gifts of God, wherby we may
in this worlde live rightly ad holilie.
But this he confuteth in that booke at
large & that substantially. So then,
true faith which bedeth on God alone
and is directed by the worde of God, is
formal enough or susficiently in fashis,
Verily the forme of faith is ingraven
in the heart ofthe faithtull, by the holy
Ghost. And although it bee small and
doth not grow up to the highest degree,
yet notwithstanding, it is true fayth
having force in it as it were a grayne
of mustardseede.
The theefe that was crucified with
our Lorde, beleeved in the Lord Jesus,
and was saved, although the force of
faith was strong in him but a verye
small season, and brought not forth a
ny great store of fruite of good workes:
finally, that faith of the theefe was not
any whit divers or contrarie from the
faith of saint Peter and sint Paul,
but was altogether ye very same with
theirs, although their faith brought
forth somwhat more aboundantly the
fruite of good workes. Peter and Paul
were frankly and freely justified, al
though they had manye good workes:
freely was the theef justified, although
his good works were very few or none
at all. Let us hold therefore, that true
faith is one alone, which notwithstan
ding doth increase & is augmented, and
again, may decrease & be ertinguished.
There remaineth now for mee to de
clare, the vertue & effect of true faith,
This hath the holy Apostle Paul done
very excellently well, yea and that
most absolutely too. But although in
the eleventh chapter to the Hebrewes
he had saide very much, he is conspel
led notwithstanding to confesse that he
cannot reckon up all: therefore at this
time I meane to rehearse a fewe ver
tues of faith, leaving the rest (deerely
beloved) to bee sought out & confidered
of your selves.
True faith before al thinges bring
eth with it true knowledge and ma
keth us wise indeede. For by faith wee
knowe God, and judge aright of the
judgementes and woorkes of God, of
vertues and vices. The wisedome that
it bringeth with it, is without doubt ye
true wisedome. Many men hope that
they can attaine to true wisedome by
the ftudie of Philosophie: but they are
deceived as farre as heaven is broade.
For Philosophie doth falsly judge, and
faultily teach many thinges touching
God, the workes of GOD, the chiefe
goodnesse, the ende of good and evil, and
touthing thinges to bee desired and es
chewed. But the verie same thinges
are rightly and truely taught in the
word of God, and understoode and per
ceived by faith. Faith therefore is the
true wisedome, and maketh us wise in
deede. For Jereme also saith. Beholde
they have cast away the worde of the
Lorde, what wisedome therefore can
there be left in them? The wisedome
of salomon, is worshipfully thought
of throughout the whole compasse of
the world. And yet we reade that the
Lord in the Gospell after S. Math, ut
tered this sentence against the Jewes.
The Egeene of the South shall rise in
judgement with this generation and
shall condemne it, because shee came
from the endes of the worlde to heare
the wisedome of salomon: et beholde
there is one in this place greater than
Salomon. Christ is preferred before
Salomon, and the wisedome of Christ
before the wisedome of salomon. But
it is well knowne that the wisedom of
Christ the sonne of God can not bee at
teyned too without faith. Faith there
fore bringeth with it the most ercellet
wisedom. But herein, this wisedom of
ours deserueth a singular prayse, be
cause they that desire it are not sent to
forreine nations, with great cost & la
bour to learne it, as to the priest of
Egypt, the Gymnosophistes of lndia,
the Philosophers of Ereece, or to the
Babines of the lewes. God hath dis
persed the worde of God throughout
the whole world, so that now the word
of faith is in the hearts of all the faith,
full. For Paule the Apostle saith. Thus
saith the justice that is of faith, saye
not in thy heart who shal descend into
heavenr that is, to fetch Christ downe
from above. Or who shall descend in
to the deepe) that is to bring Christ
from the dead againe. But what saith,
he) The worde is nigh unto thee even
in thy heart: this same is the worde of
faith which we preach, for if thou co
fesse with thy mouth the Lord lesus,
and doest beleeve with thy heart that
God hath raised him from the dead
thou shalt be saved. Faith therefore
doth not onely make us wise but hap
pie also, the Lord himself bearing wit
nes thereunto & saying to his disciples.
Nappie are the eyes that see the things
that ye see. For l say unto you that ma
nie prophetes and kinges have desired
to see the things that ye seeret to heare
the thinges that ye heare, et heard the
not. We shall therfore finde in faith, a
most certaine determination of ye most
notalbequestion stirred in, since the be
ginning of the world, of learned & most
excellent wits, which is: by what mea
nes a man may live, be happy, attaine
to the chiefe goodnes, be ioyned to the
chiefe goodnes, & so be justified: There
have been, yea & yet are, divers opinios
touthing this matter, cotrarie the one
to the other. But we do briefely & truly
affirme, that by true faith a man doth
live, is happy, attaineth to ye chief good
nes, is conioyned to the chief goodnes, &
also justified: so ye god dwelleth in us, &
we in him, & that by faith we are both
happy and blessed. What I pray you
could have beene spoke more excellently
worthily or divinely, touching true
faith: for se, faith quikneth us, maketh
us happy, ioineth us to the chiefe good
nes, so ye he in us & we in him may live,
& faith doth also fully justifie us. But
now it is best to heare the testimonies
out of the scriptures. Faith maketh us
happy. For to S. Pet, confessing ye lord
Jesus by true faith it is sayde. Bappie
art thou simon the son of Jonas. Vlesh
and bloud hath not revealed this to
thee, but my father which is in heave.
S. Paul for the proofe of faith bringeth
in that sentence of David. Happi are
they whose iniduities are forgiven and
whose sinnes are covered. Plessed is
the man to who the Lord shall impute
no sinne. Faith dquickneth or maketh a
live. For the just liveth by faith. This
doth Paule very often in his writings
alledge out of the prophets. The same
Paul also saith: The life which nowI
live in flesh, I live by faith in the sonne
of God, who lovedmee and gave him
selfe for me. Faith ioineth us to ye eter
nall & chiefe goodnes, & so maketh us to
inioy ye chief goodnes, ye god may dwell
in us & we in God. For the Lord Jesus
himselfe in the gospell saith. He which
eateth my flesh, &t drinketh my bloud
dwelleth in me, et I in him. As the ly
ving father sent me, so also l live by the
father, et he that eateth me shal live by
me. But to eate & drinkye Lord is to be
lieve in ye Lord, ye he hath given himself
to death for us. Wherupon Johnye A
postle saith. we have seene et do wit
nesse, that the father hath sent the son
the saviour of the worlde. whosoever
shall confesse that lesus is the sonne of
God, God dwelleth in him and he in
God. Wherefore also Paul said: I live
now, not l, but Christ liveth in me,
Moreover faith doth justifie,
But for because the treatise therof can
no
ende of this houre, I meane to deferre
it till the next Sermon that shall bee,
At this present (dearely beloeved) yee
must rememder, that there is but one
true faith that is the Christian faith,
For although there be said to be many
faithes, that is religions, yet notwith
standing there is onely but one true
and undoubted faith. And that doth
increase and againe decrease in some
men. As for those in whom it is right
ly and godly obserued, in them it shew
eth foorth sundrie vertues. For it
bringeth with it true wisedome, final
ly, it quickneth and maketh us blessed
and happy in deede. To God the father
the author of all goodnesse, and of our
felicitie, be al praise and glorie through
Jesus Christ our Lord, for ever and e
ver. Amen
